block.p: 2 Die in West Bank Clash, Straining New Cease-Fire An army-escorted hike by three dozen Jewish settlers in the West Bank touched off a protracted firefight that weakened expectations that the two-day-old cease-fire agreement would take hold. The seven-hour clash left two dead, one Israeli and one Palestinian. They were the first deaths since Israeli and Palestinian leaders agreed in Egypt this week to halt the violence.

Blast Inquiry in Yemen The investigation into the attack on the destroyer Cole has led to a mountainous tribal region on Yemen's eastern border with Saudi Arabia that became a stronghold of Islamic terror groups returning from fighting Soviet forces in Afghanistan.

The seven-hour clash left two dead, one Israeli and one Palestinian. They were the first deaths since Israeli and Palestinian leaders agreed in Egypt this week to halt the violence.

Blast Inquiry in Yemen The investigation into the attack on the destroyer Cole has led to a mountainous tribal region on Yemen's eastern border with Saudi Arabia that became a stronghold of Islamic terror groups returning from fighting Soviet forces in Afghanistan.

In late May, the Clinton administration warned American diplomatic and military posts in Yemen and other Mideast countries that a militant Egyptian Islamic group was in the final stages of preparing a terror attack against American targets.
Officials in Washington are questioning whether security lapses aided the people who attacked the Cole.

Afghan Opium Crop Declines Opium production in Afghanistan dropped 28 percent this year because of widespread drought and a United Nations crop-substitution program, the senior United Nations drug-control official said at an international conference on drug trafficking and terrorism in Central Asia.
Hunger Persists in Iraq Tun Myat, the administrator of the United Nations ''oil for food'' program in Iraq, said many ordinary Iraqis were malnourished despite more efficient Iraqi distribution.

U.S.-Jordan Trade Pact The United States and Jordan plan to sign a free trade agreement next week. The deal is seen as supporting a partner in the Middle East peace process while helping Vice President Al Gore show he can reinvent the way trade deals are done.

Armenia Resolution Withdrawn Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, acting minutes before a scheduled House vote, pulled a resolution condemning mass killings of Armenians in Turkey 85 years ago. He cited President Clinton's warning that a vote could harm national security and hurt relations with Turkey, a key NATO ally.
Disputed Dam to Be Built An Indian Supreme Court decision will allow the long-stalled construction of the Sardar Sarovar dam on the Narmada to resume Oct. 31.

Salvadoran Knew of Abuses The retired head of the Salvadoran National Guard admitted in a Florida courtroom that he knew that his troops, five of whom were convicted in the killings of four American churchwomen in 1980, had been involved in the torture and killings of civilians when he was appointed to the lead the guard in 1979.

Once Close to Clinton, Gore Keeps His Distance Vice President Al Gore is keeping his distance from President Clinton, to what is said to be the puzzlement and consternation of the president, who believes his political heir needs the campaign advice that Mr. Clinton is anxious to give. Gore aides say such a distancing is a must.
Mr. Gore said Gov. George W. Bush's tax cut proposal would drain Social Security, jack up interest rates and undermine economic growth.
Several prominent Capitol Hill Democrats questioned Mr. Bush's capacity to lead, a theme that Gore surrogates plan to voice repeatedly.

Bush Fires Back at Ads Gov. George W. Bush, striking back at Democratic commercials attacking his Social Security plan, said Vice President Al Gore was pitting ''grandparents against grandchildren'' for political gain and accused him of not facing up to Social Security's coming fiscal problems.
Mr. Bush appeared on the ''Late Show with David Letterman,'' where the comedian grilled him on the death penalty, violence in the Mideast and pollution in Texas.

Clinton Balks at Interim Bills President Clinton said he would no longer sign stopgap spending measures and sought to inject a sense of urgency into slow-moving Congressional deliberations over bills to keep the government running.

G.O.P. Plan for Medicare Republican Congressional leaders agreed on a plan to pump $28 billion into Medicare over five years, mainly by increasing payments to H.M.O.'s and other providers. The president opposes that approach.

Remaking High School System Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy is proposing a far-reaching plan to change the way most students are assigned to New York City high schools, with an emphasis on creating more neighborhood choices.

Filtering the Net for Students A commission appointed by Congress has decided to oppose efforts to make schools and libraries install software to block Internet access to pornography and other material deemed harmful to minors.

12 Indicted in Effort To Break a Crime Family Federal authorities and the police announced a murder and racketeering indictment that they said would devastate the DeCavalcante crime family by breaking its grip on businesses and labor unions in New York and New Jersey. Officials say the organization helped pioneer some of the mob's earliest stock schemes on and off Wall Street and that some members fancy themselves as models for ''Sopranos'' characters.

Rivals Break Bread The annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner, a charity fund-raiser, brought under one roof Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, and Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio.

Call to Ban Drug Ingredient An F.D.A. advisory panel urged that a common ingredient in over-the-counter decongestants and appetite suppressants, phenylpropanolamine, be banned because it may increase the risk of stroke in young women.

An AIDS Virus Under Control Researchers using a new kind of vaccine made from DNA said they were able to control a strain of AIDS virus in monkeys by keeping its level so low that it was virtually undetectable in the animals' blood.
Everglades Renewal The House, voting 394 to 14, approved a $7.8 billion plan to revive the Florida Everglades. The Senate earlier passed a different version.

Subway Series Lineups The Mets announced that Al Leiter, not Mike Hampton, would start Game 1 tomorrow against the Yankees. Hampton will pitch Game 2, followed by Rick Reed and Bobby J. Jones. The Yanks pitching order will be Andy Pettitte, Roger Clemens and Orlando Hernandez, with signs that David Cone will start Game 4.

Going After Offshore Accounts The I.R.S., pursuing billions in unreported personal income taxes, asked a federal judge to issue summonses for records of MasterCard and American Express transactions in the United States that were billed to Caribbean bank accounts.

An Old-Economy Deal United Technologies, one of the last old-style conglomerates, whose array of products includes jet engines and elevators, was said to be preparing to announce that it will buy Honeywell for $40.3 billion in stock.

Tech Stocks Lead Rally The Nasdaq surged 247.04 points, or 7.79 percent, to 3,418.60, narrowing its loss for the year to 16 percent. The Dow crossed back above 10,000, gaining 167.96 points, or 1.7 percent, to 10,142.98. The S.& P. 500 rose 46.63 points, or 3.5 percent, to 1,388.76.

A Big Investor Gets His Way Warren E. Buffett asked for -- and got -- the resignation of Gillette's chief executive, Michael C. Hawley, as the company announced another disappointing quarter of earnings.
Higher Pay at Coke Coca-Cola, struggling to keep employees after a turbulent year, is offering raises ranging from less than $1,000 to as much as $15,000.
